    Expected Value

    2 minute read

    A key realization that I had early in life, although in much more primitive terms, is that all you can ever hope to affect is the expected value of your decisions. Certainty, no matter how much we crave for it, simply isn’t attainable in most real life situations.

    It’s also become obvious to me, gradually over many years, that most people never had this realization or, if they did, don’t properly incorporate it into their life.

    In fact, many phallacies and cognitive biases are rooted in people misunderstanding expected values:

    • The Hot Hand Phallacy – incorreclty assuming that recent successes increase the probability for future successes,
    • The Gambler’s Phallacy – failing to distinguish between expected values and dependent expected values,
    • The Risk Aversion Bias – the tendency for people to trade expected value for a reduced perceived risk,
    • The Disposition Effect – selling assets that have increased in value and keeping assets that have dropped in value regardless of the expected value of those decisions,
    • The Information Bias – seeking information when faced with a decision even if the potentially gained information won’t affect the expected value of any of the options at hand,
    • Loss Aversion – refusing to take up an opportunity of positive expected value because losses are valued more than wins of equal magnitude,
    • …

    Expected Value

    Suppose I proposed the following game of chance to you: We flip a fair coin and every time it shows heads, you pay me $2. Every time is shows tails, I pay you $1.

    In this simple scenario, people know inuitively that they’re very likely to lose their money to me and hence correctly refuse to play. However, only slighly less obvious rip-offs attract an enormous amount of people who happily invest their money (state lotteries, slot machines, various unfavorable insurance schemes, …). The expected value is a tool to protect us against these schemes and, on the other hand, recognize favorable opportunities:

    A (finite 1) Stochastic Experiment consists of a number of potential results together with a payoff (a real number) and a probability that is associated to each . We have

    • for all ,
    • 2 and
    • for and more generally for all .

    The Expected Value (EV) of this Stochastic Experiment is the average pay-off, calculated as

    In our example above there are two potential results: , with payoffs , and . The expected value is

    This means that, on average, you will lose every time you agree to play against me. So, after 100 games, you will, on average, have lost .

    There will be fluctuations, of course. And it may be tempting to chase your furtune. You might even win the first 10 games and quit – leaving you with a profit of . But it’s a mathematical fact that trying to beat the expected value is a foolish attempt.

    If that doesn’t convince you, let’s look at a few simulations of your overall winnings:
